captions.text:
It makes intuitive sense that objects like
circles and spheres are round - but what is

it about a sphere that makes it round? If
you're talking about how effective a shape

is at enclosing a large volume, you mean "sphericity".
And a sphere is the shape that contains the

most volume with the least surface area, that
is, a sphere is the most "spherical" shape.

But roundness has more to do with rolling
than with volume, right? A round object can

roll smoothly - like a wheel or ball bearing.
And the main feature that ball bearings need

in order to roll smoothly is to be the same
width from bottom to top/one side to the other.

It turns out there are plenty of non-circular
'shapes of constant width' that are excellent

bearings as well. The Reuleaux rotor, for
example, is made up of segments from three

circles intersecting at their centers - so
every point on a side is the same distance

from the opposite corner, and the rotor rolls
around wonderfully. In fact, the Reuleaux
rotor can even turn smoothly in a square hole!

But don't try to use a Reuleaux rotor for
the wheel on your car - since they're not

a constant distance from the axle, those points
will make for a bumpy ride! In fact, the points

on a Reuleaux rotor are just that - pointy.
Doesn't that go against the idea of roundness?

Geology has the answer: stones with sharp
or rough edges that are worn away become "rounded."

So we might say a Reuleaux rotor is round
but not rounded. On the other hand, certain

British coins are round AND rounded, though
they're still not circles: the 20 and 50-p

coins are shapes of constant width, which
means they look un-circularly cool but don't
get stuck in coin machines!

And isn't if funny that "rouleau" means "roll"
in French and Franz Reuleaux invented a rolling
rotor?

comments.text:
Why would this round triangle not work as car tires? Because, although the 
diameter is the same all around, there is no set radius, the measurement 
which defines a circle. The radius is the distance from the center to the 
edge. Since a car tire rotates around its center, it requires a set radius 
for a smooth ride.﻿

comments.text:
Yeah, sorry I was unclear.I get that there is a centre of mass, but no 
centre of rotation, because if there were it would rotate around it and 
move smoothly. How you would design a gear mechanism like that sounds 
pretty incredible though. I would definetley watch that video.
comments.author: Monty Evans

comments.text:
+Monty Evans Although the center of this shape is not half way along its 
diameter, it does in fact have a set center (as defined by a point around 
which the area of a shape is equally distributed). If you were to place a 
hole through the center and attempt to roll it like a wheel, it would not 
be a smooth ride. However, it would be possible to compensate for the 
unevenness using a gear mechanism, which in text would be difficult to 
describe... maybe I'll make a video about it.
comments.author: TheHelvetican

comments.text:
because wheels need to be fixed to the car by an axle, right? And the key 
difference between the rouleau shape and a circle is that while a circle 
has a fixed centre the rouleau shape does not have a fixed centre, the 
centre of rotation gradually moves as the shape moves, so while you can use 
it to roll when there is no axle, like as a log, t can't roll when fixed to 
an axle, because then its centre of rotation would be fixed, and it can't 
roll that way.
comments.author: Monty Evans

comments.text:
+7000000th but being used in conjunction with other words to translate to 
something is different. "rouleau" itself means roller. lots of words change 
meanings when added to others, especially during translations. when 
translating, the general meaning is used. for example, "bonjour" means 
"hello", right? well, there's also the direct translations. in this case, 
"bonjour" directly translates to good day ("bon" meaning good, "jour" 
meaning day). by translating the point, then yes, rouleau du papier is a 
paper roll. but the direct translation is "roller of paper". "rouleau à 
patisserie" means rolling pin, but the direct translation is actually 
"roller of pastry".
finally, your point still doesn't prove them right, as they said it means 
"rolling". the world "rouleau" itself means roller. when giving 
translations for the meaning of words, not direct translations, it can have 
anything to do with the word "roll" (staying as "roller", becoming "roll", 
becoming "rolling"), but the word alone means roller.
comments.author: tubefan90000

comments.text:
it could actually translate as "roll", like in "rouleau de papier" (paper 
roll), or "roller" as in a tool you use to flatten stuff ("rouleau à 
pâtisserie", "rolling pin")

comments.text:
another way to make a round shape is to take any polygon with an odd amount 
of sides, and take a protractor and put the point on one corner and draw an 
arc joining the two opposite corners. do this on all sides. you now have a 
round shape with corners congrats you have a round shape!﻿

comments.text:
BATMAN



Screenplay by

Sam Hamm



Based on the Character Created by

Bob Kane






FIRST DRAFT

October 20, 1986








FADE IN:

EXT. CITYSCAPE - NIGHT

The place is Gotham City. The time, 1987 -- once removed.

The city of Tomorrow: stark angles, creeping shadows, 
dense, crowded, airless, a random tangle of steel and 
concrete, self-generating, almost subterranean in its 
aspect... as if hell had erupted through the sidewalks and 
kept on growing. A dangling fat moon shines overhead, ready 
to burst.

EXT. CATHEDRAL - NIGHT

Amid the chrome and glass sits a dark and ornate Gothic 
anomaly: old City Cathedral, once grand, now abandoned -- 
long since boarded up and scheduled for demolition.

On the rooftop far above us, STONE GARGOYLES gaze down from 
their shadowy, windswept perches, keeping monstrous watch 
over the distant streets below, sightless guardians of the 
Gotham night.

One of them is moving.

EXT. GOTHAM SQUARE - NIGHT

The pulsing heart of downtown Gotham, a neon nightmare of 
big-city corruption, almost surreal in its oppressiveness. 
Hookers wave to drug dealers. Street hustlers slap high-
fives with three-card monte dealers. They all seem to know﻿

comments.text:
+cwjakesteel and that's twice as sad, because I think a (anything)-teacher 
should feel even more responsible than a (anything)-ist, because he or she 
has the minds of young people in his or her own hands! With enough passion 
and desire to transmit the knowledge and sense of beauty of the subject 
taught, the teacher can make or break a young student's future choices in 
life. I've seen one too many teachers make smart students feel stupid and 
lose passion in an otherwise interesting courses of study, and I'm talking 
high school, not university (where usually the student is less cradled 
because he or she has already made a choice). My literature teacher in 
middle school was a really passionate man, he read us poetry and he could 
almost be seen crying in front of the class when reading "A Silvia", a 
tragic, heart-rending poem. And I myself cried when he was reading it. When 
my high school teacher had to explain the same poem in high school, she 
said "Well, all of you surely know this famous poem, so we'll skip reading 
it and start with the analisys: first thing we notice is that the first and 
last words of the first stanza are anagrams"... WHAT? No, bitch, the first 
thing I notice is that this guy writing the poem is bleeding his heart out 
for the girl he loved who is now dead, and the second thing I notice is 
that you are a heartless monster!

My 2 Cents :)
comments.author: Walthanar
